Class GameServer

java.lang.Object
edu.io.net.server.GameServer
public class GameServer extends Object
High-level game server coordinating game logic and handling game-related commands received via a lower-level TCPServer.

This class represents the domain layer of the server-side architecture. It does not deal with network sockets directly. Instead, it relies on an instance of TCPServer which performs all TCP handling, connection acceptance and raw command dispatching.

Responsibilities

  • maintaining and manipulating the Game instance representing the core game logic,
  • registering handlers for all supported command types,
  • processing commands in a per-client context,
  • sending game updates or broadcast messages via the underlying TCPServer,
  • performing validation (e.g., protocol version checks),
  • constructing and returning appropriate CommandAck responses.

All clients are represented by Client objects created within TCPServer, which provides thread-safe I/O streams and metadata such as connection timestamp and a per-client semaphore for synchronous writes.

Threading model

TCPServer creates one virtual thread per client and invokes the registered command handler callback on that thread. All command methods in this class run within those threads. Game logic methods may therefore be invoked concurrently.

Game state synchronization

Command handlers may issue broadcasts using TCPServer.broadcast(Command) to synchronize updated game state with all currently connected clients.

  • Constructor Details

    • GameServer

      public GameServer(int port)
      Creates a new game server instance bound to the given TCP port.

      This constructor initializes both major subsystems:

      • a low-level TCPServer responsible for accepting client connections and dispatching incoming commands,
      • a Game instance representing the core game logic and in-memory world state.

      After constructing both components, the method registers all supported command handlers by invoking setupCommandRouter(), effectively wiring the domain-level logic to the network transport layer.

      Parameters:
      port - the TCP port on which the server will listen for incoming client connections

  • Method Details

    • start

      public void start()
      Starts the game server, including both the game logic loop and the underlying TCP subsystem.

      The method performs two high-level actions in order:

      1. invokes Game.start() to initialize or reset the internal game state and begin any game-specific background processes,
      2. starts the TCPServer, which begins accepting client connections and dispatching incoming commands to the handlers registered during construction.

      If the TCP layer fails to start due to an IOException, the error is logged and the server remains inactive.

      Threading: Once started, the TCP server creates a dedicated virtual thread for each connected client. All command handlers defined in this class are executed on those threads.
